Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Roads and Accidents in Kenya

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Columbia University doctoral student Amiel Melnick, under the guidance of Dr. Rosalind Morris, will undertake research on traffic accidents and roads in Kenya. Through an examination of the role of traffic accidents in Kenyan policy and public discourse, the regulatory techniques of road safety interventions, and the lived experience of those who travel on roads known as "death stretches," this research will consider the relationship of infrastructure, social practice, and everyday hazards. Focusing on the expert calculation and bureaucratic management of traffic accidents, as well as moral and practical responses on the part of accident victims and their families, religious leaders, and the Kenyan public more generally, this study aims to provide an empirically grounded account of the everyday management of road traffic accidents that will contribute to discussions of infrastructure, contingency, and risk management in African contexts.

The research will involve social science methods such as interviews, participant observation, archival analysis, and GIS mapping in both the capital Nairobi and an accident "black spot" (a stretch of road that sees frequent accidents). The study will both describe the burden of coping with accidental death and injury in everyday life and offer critical purchase on international and local road safety interventions. It will expand the social scientific study of infrastructure with an ethnographic case study of accident-prone "black spots" in Kenya. The project will also rework classic anthropological questions on contingency and hazard, which have traditionally been focused on occult causation, by studying a range of epistemological frameworks for understanding "accidents."

Traffic accidents, which are a leading cause of death and injury in Africa, remain understudied by social scientists. The researchers will share their findings with a broad range of audiences in an attempt to inform road construction and road safety efforts in Kenya and beyond. The project will also contribute to the training of a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant supported research entitled Black Spots; Roads and Road Danger in Kenya. This research, conducted by Amiel Bize Melnick, took place over 22 months in three different sites. It investigated how the East African country’s ideological and financial investment in roads affects everyday life in rural areas. It surveyed official and popular management of road risk, and, in particular, how rural populations anticipate and react to road accidents. The bulk of the research took place in two rural roadside settlements located at black spots—stretches of road where accidents occur with unusual frequency.

The two rural settlements in which the fieldwork was conducted are both areas in transition, surrounded by farmland but subjected to increasing urbanizing pressures. The first, Shimalabandu (the name translates as “place that finishes people”), is located along the A1, Kenya’s main north-south highway. It is surrounded by smallholder farms in an area with one of the world’s highest rural population densities. The second, Salgaa, is a new truck stop settlement on the A104, the most important highway in Eastern Africa, and a transport corridor for cargo moving to and from the port of Mombasa. Salgaa is surrounded by vast expanses of land owned by wealthy colonial-era settlers and Kenya's political elite, but is itself a bustling township offering a variety of services to truckers. Topography and road design work alongside increasing human and vehicular traffic to make both of these sites for particularly regular, often spectacular, traffic accidents.

The field research conducted with the support of this grant included participant-observation work with officials and local residents in both areas, as well as archival research and interviews in the capital, Nairobi. Through research with traffic police, insurance investigators and executives, directors of road safety organizations, owners and employees of trucking companies, staff of the National Highway Authority, and directors of the National Transport Safety Authority, evidence was gathered about the regulatory and policy reaction to an incidence of road accidents so severe it has been declared a “national disaster.” Data was also collected by observing and documenting reactions to recent accidents with the public on site, and through media reports. Further, through the personal narratives expressed in visits with victims of road accidents and the families of casualties; discourse at funerals; interviews with a range of transport workers; and vehicle post-mortems at a car repair workshop, the research engaged with the intricate and often contradictory processes of knowledge production around and management of road accidents.

This research will be described in a dissertation that examines the effects of road accidents, and their anticipation, on rural areas. The dissertation argues accidents become regularized in two ways: as objects of knowledge and through the institutions that grow up to manage them. Knowledge around accidents is created and exploited by diverse officials, including government departments, regulators, insurance companies, and the police, in an attempt to regulate mobility, justify increasing expenditure on infrastructure construction, and access the untapped markets represented by lower-income populations. Accidents involve rural residents in webs of formal and informal institutions (hospitals, police, insurance agents, lawyers, churches, family networks) that assist with care and restitution in spiritual and material ways, but often in ways that harm as much as they help.
